case_title: Messrs DUTY FREE SHOP LTD vs CENTRAL BOARD OF REVENUE and others
reference_no_or_id: Constitutional Petitions Nos.D-847, D-1865 and D-1930 of 1997

prosecution: S. Tariq A.I (Standing Counsel for Federal Government)

complaint_summary: Petitioners, engaged in running Duty Free Shops, hold private warehouse licenses and store goods in bonded warehouses. They challenged the imposition of withholding tax under Section 50(5) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1979, arguing that such goods are not technically imported into Pakistan and thus should not attract withholding tax.
investigation_summary: Petitioners argued that goods stored in private bonded warehouses were not technically imported into Pakistan, and thus withholding tax under Section 50(5) was not applicable. They relied on past practices, departmental letters, and administrative interpretations supporting their stance.
judgment_summary: The court ruled that withholding tax under Section 50(5) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1979, cannot be levied on goods stored in private bonded warehouses until they are cleared for home consumption. Notices and demands for withholding tax on such goods were declared invalid.
Decision_or_verdict: Petition allowed; withholding tax demands declared invalid.
legal_arguments: Goods stored in private bonded warehouses are not technically imported into Pakistan.
Customs duty and withholding tax are payable only upon clearance for home consumption.
Section 50(5) requires withholding tax to be collected in the same manner and at the same time as customs duty.
citations: Canada Sugar Company v. The Queen (1898) AC 735
Nazeer Ahmed v. Pakistan CE&LC PLD 1988 SC 370
Asian Food Industries Ltd. v. Pakistan 1985 SCMR 1753
Eduljee Dinshaw Ltd. v. Income Tax Officer 1990 PTD 155
East West Steamship Company v. Collector of Customs PLD 1976 SC 618
English Biscuit Manufacturers Ltd. v. Assistant Collector 1991 PTD 478
Central Insurance Company v. Central Board of Revenue 1992 SCMR 1232
key_issues: Applicability of withholding tax under Section 50(5) to goods stored in private bonded warehouses.
Executive interpretation of tax provisions and its binding nature.
Impact of administrative interpretations and past practices on statutory provisions.

maxims.Estoppel: Executive practices relied upon for a considerable period cannot be casually altered.

legal_terms.Withholding Tax: Tax collected at source on income or transactions.
legal_terms.Bonded Warehouse: Secured storage facility for goods awaiting customs clearance.

words_and_phrases.Technically Imported: Goods not cleared for home consumption or export while stored in bonded warehouses.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the applicability of withholding tax under Section 50(5) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1979, to goods stored in private bonded warehouses. The court ruled that such tax could not be levied until customs duty is payable upon clearance for home consumption. Past practices, administrative interpretations, and statutory provisions were considered in the judgment.

summary.facts: Petitioners, engaged in running Duty Free Shops, hold private warehouse licenses and store goods in bonded warehouses. They challenged the imposition of withholding tax under Section 50(5) of the Income Tax Ordinance, 1979, arguing that such goods are not technically imported into Pakistan and thus should not attract withholding tax.
summary.decision: The court ruled that withholding tax under Section 50(5) cannot be levied on goods stored in private bonded warehouses until they are cleared for home consumption. Notices and demands for withholding tax on such goods were declared invalid.
summary.majority_opinion: Wajihuddin Ahmed and Ghous Muhammad held that withholding tax is payable only at the same time and in the same manner as customs duty, which is deferred for goods stored in warehouses.
summary.dissenting_opinion: Raja Qureshi argued that withholding tax becomes payable even when goods are sent to warehouses, irrespective of their clearance for home consumption.
